Dispute_Type: Human rights complaint regarding employment termination
Legal_Issue: Whether the CHRC failed to afford procedural fairness and whether its decision was patently unreasonable
Governing_Law: Canadian Human Rights Act, Sections 41 and 42
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Tse failed to provide crucial evidence to support claims of bias or procedural unfairness
Decision_Outcome: CHRC declined jurisdiction due to late filing
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant (Mr. Tse) to demonstrate procedural unfairness or unreasonableness
Credibility_Factor: Lack of evidence from Mr. Tse undermined credibility of claims
Legal_Rule: Complaints must be filed within one year unless extension is granted; standard of patent unreasonableness applies on review
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached – complaint dismissed on procedural grounds
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No violation found; CHRC's process deemed fair
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of termination, date of complaint filing, lack of supporting evidence for bias
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, procedural fairness principles
Applicant_Challenge: CHRC’s refusal to accept late-filed complaint and alleged bias
Legal_Rule_Source: Section 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities for procedural issues; high threshold for patent unreasonableness
Defendant_Response: CHRC asserted lack of jurisdiction due to untimely filing
Evidence_Type: Documentary (filing dates), absence of evidence on bias
Outcome: No remedy granted; CHRC decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Overturning CHRC's decision not to deal with the complaint
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Complaint filed 14 months after termination – outside statutory time limit
Applicable_Process: Filing of human rights complaint, CHRC screening, judicial review
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian Human Rights Act
